Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on June 25, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (4) At least 1 adult member of the household
must have training in and maintain a current
certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary
resuscitation from the American Heart
Association or the American Red Cross, or other
institution approved by the department.
One of three foster home files reviewed did not have documentation of current
CPR/First Aid training as required.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.

Two of three foster home files reviewed did not document preferred placement
specifications regarding SOGIE.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (4) Before completion of the written report
required by subrule (6) of this rule, an agency
shall provide the foster parent with a verbal
summary of the preliminary findings at the
conclusion of the evaluation.
One of two special investigation report reviewed did have documentation the
foster parents were provided a verbal summary of preliminary findings at the
conclusion of the evaluation as required.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
• (3) The agency shall document all the following
in the child's record before a change of
placement occurs:
• (a) Reason for the change in placement.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not document the reason for the
placement change in the child's record.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child’s parents;
the department licensing authority; the
lawyer guardian ad litem and court; as
applicable;the department; and foster
child’s parents, if any of the following
occurs:
• (iv) Any medical and mental
illness or condition that results in
treatment at a hospital emergency
room or inpatient hospitalization of
a foster child.

Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have an incident report completed
and provided to the department licensing authority as required.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlines in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – wihtin 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption

At least three business days prior to a planned change
of placement or no later than three business days after
an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
stepdown from a residential or hospital setting, return
from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Five of eight foster care files reviewed, and two of three independent living files
reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/27/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/8/2023
7/6/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 8/2/2022
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker muste enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
Six of eight foster care files reviewed, and one of three independent living files
reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not
uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/27/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/8/2023
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
After the caseworker routes the service plan to the
supervisor for review and approval, the supervisor must
approve all case service plans within 14 days of the
end of the report period.
One of eight foster care files reviewed, and one of three independent living files
reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case service plan within 14
days as required.

FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardians(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement
agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
d esignee.
Five of eight foster care files reviewed, and one of three independent living files
reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency
treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/27/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/8/2023
7/6/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 8/2/2022
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider
• Youth adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must
be documented in the electronic case management
record.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child’s current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is
temporary could ward.
• Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
• At reunification. Subsequent medical passports
are not required after reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.

• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to
each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and
accepted for treatemnt or services prior to or at
the first schedule appointment while the foster
care case is open regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young
adults aged 18 and older).
• YAVFC youth/young adult.
Four of eight foster care files reviewed, and three and three independent living
files reviewed did not have medical passports completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7/27/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/8/2023
7/6/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 8/2/2022

• Annotate on PATP’s if parents refuse to sign, not able to be located, etc. and
include the date.
• FOM 722-06B FTM outlines scenarios when an FTM can be held despite
parents not attending.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency Interim inspection was completed on 7/27/2023 and the CAP was
approved on 9/8/2023. The agency was cited for 14 violations, 5 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 5, there was an improvement in medical passports.
There was a slight increase in the number of PATP signatures not obtained or not
obtained timely, missed FTM's and DHS 1105 forms not uploaded or not uploaded
timely. The number of incidents of noncompliance regarding independent living
contracts remained the same. In 2022, 30 violations were established, 5 of which
were repeated this year. The agency will need to establish additional corrective
planning for the repeated violations to ensure a reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the agency has experienced some difficulties addressing certain
violations over the past few years. For the previous year CAP, the supervisory
team sought out new techniques to address these violations. Additional oversight
has also shown to be effective. The agency focused on being more creative when
developing the previous year’s CAP. The agency has held ongoing trainings for
staff that address CAP items as well as other compliance items. In addition, the
agency regularly holds supervisory meetings to review overall compliance. The
assessment noted the agency has experienced staff stability over the last review
period and the CA feels confident there will be improvement over the next review
period.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility’s
budget and the agency’s financial audit.
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing, and adoption services. All files were stored
securely and there is a cross shredder for CHRI.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
